awd_titl_txt: RUI: Tests of Gravity, Data Analysis, and Detector Characterization for LIGO
awd_abstract_narration:
An exciting era in gravitational wave physics and astronomy has begun as the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) and the Virgo Observatory have now detected gravitational waves from several binary black hole mergers and a binary neutron star merger. Interpreting the scientific implications from these events and detecting additional sources of gravitational waves will make a significant contribution to our understanding of nature. Events seen by LIGO produce a wealth of astrophysical information and information on gravity theory. The extraction and interpretation of that information will require advanced techniques in data analysis, parameter estimation, statistics, and phenomenology. Detector characterization work will provide scientists with confidence in the quality of the data, and the performance of the detectors. Carleton College will continue with its efforts in identifying and characterizing noise in LIGO data. The use of LIGO to search for a stochastic gravitational wave background will continue at Carleton, and the Carleton team will continue to develop the implications of those results for astrophysics and gravitational physics. The team will also continue to develop the tools to perform and interpret multimessenger astrophysics.

Carleton College is a leader in producing future scientists. This project will provide research opportunities to students with interests in physics and related fields, and help train them to become the next generation of scientists. Carleton students are eager to participate in exciting research, and their interest in gravitational wave astronomy, tests of General Relativity, and science in general, is large. The methods and results developed as a consequence of this project have, and will continue to have, significant influence in other scientific fields: astrophysics, gravitational wave detectors in space, and alternative gravity theory. The project will continue to provide material that will improve teaching at the college level and it will create opportunities for scientific outreach at Carleton, in the local community, and in the K-12 schools. This outreach generates much excitement for science and physics. Finally, the research work of this project promotes international scientific collaboration. Albert Einstein predicted the existence of gravitational waves in 1916; a century later we observed them. They will now tell us new things about the universe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant has provided resources for the faculty and their students at Carleton College to perform gravitational wave research with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO). This work was performed within three subcategories.

Detector characterization: to detect the tiny ripples in spacetime that form gravitational waves, the LIGO instrument must be extremely sensitive, which causes it to be affected by many environmental influences besides gravitational waves. Before further science is possible, the nature of both the noise and the signal detected by the instrument must be understood. This is the job of detector characterization. The Carleton group contributed to these efforts by developing and implementing data analysis tools that identify and help to eliminate environmental noise in the gravitational wave data stream.

Testing general relativity: gravitational waves are a prediction of general relativity. Their first observation provided initial confirmation of this prediction. As we observe more gravitational waves, we can further test the details of the theory of general relativity. The Carleton group was involved in several of these tests primarily focused on how gravitational waves travel through space from their source to the LIGO detectors. General relativity predicts that gravitational waves travel at the speed of light independent of factors such as their direction of travel, frequency, and polarization. Our studies confirm this prediction with significantly improved confidence. Some of these tests require a comparison between the travel time of light and gravitational waves from the same event. The Carleton team has worked closely with groups from NASA's Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor and Swift Observatory to implement these and other tests requiring such coordination.

Stochastic gravitational waves: the Carleton team also participates in efforts to observe a stochastic background of gravitational waves with ground-based detectors. These waves could be produced, for example, in the creation of the universe, the Big Bang, and permeate all points of space today. They can also be generated by the combined hum of the many binary black hole and neutron star mergers that have occurred over the history of the universe. While ground-based detectors have yet to observe a stochastic background, important limits on its intensity have been set.

Perhaps the most important outcome of this grant has been the amazing research opportunities that it has created for Carleton College undergraduates. Because of these research projects the students have been trained in exciting scientific research, and have gone on to some of the best graduate schools in the United States. The educational benefits provided by this grant have been outstanding. This has helped to train the next generation of scientists.
